content: She put on a breathtaking show at Sunday night's Coronation concert.

Yet Katy Perry's choice of outfit put her renditions of Firework and Roar paired with incredible staging in the dark a little - as viewers were distracted by her dress.The singer, 38, looked incredible in a gold lamé Vivienne Westwood gown, which was compared - rather hilariously - to a Quality Street Toffee Penny. The iconic gold sweet from Mackintosh's beloved selection box of treats is wrapped in gold foil layered beneath clear plastic and was undeniably quite similar to Katy's plunging gown, which featured a full skirt and structured top. Viewers took to Twitter to pen: 'Katy Perry / Quality Street Toffee Penny... i guess katy perry dug into the quality street box for this dress...

'Katy Perry paying respects to UK by dressing as a Quality Street... cute of katy perry to pay tribute to the uk by dressing as everyone’s least favourite quality street...   'Katy Perry saving the planet by using quality street sweet wrappers to make her frock... Katy Perry rocking a Quality Street Toffee Penny wrapper... 'Katy Perry looks like is a gorgeous quality street. Absolutely love... Love how Katy Perry is wearing a Quality Street wrapper... Katy Perry is my favourite Quality Street...'Very patriotic of Katy Perry to come dressed as penny toffee out of Quality Street... Katy Perry newly cosplaying as the toffee penny Quality Street... Fab performance from Katy Perry and her outfit gives me Quality Street 'Toffee Penny' vibes'.

After performing at the concert, Katy shared backstage details with her Instagram followers. She joined stars including Lionel Richie and Take That in lighting up the stage at Windsor Castle in honour of King Charles III. In the early hours of Monday morning, she took to the photosharing site to show the inside of the Vivienne Westwood she wore on stage. The lining of the vast gold lamé ballgown featured delicate embroidery reading: 'Katy Perry [Crown symbol] Charles III 2023 VW'. She also revealed her Pentecostal pastor mother Mary Perry was in tow, as she shared a snap of the duo hugging, while her British husband Orlando Bloo

Katy took to the stage at King Charles and Queen Camilla's Concert, where she looked sensational in a huge gold metallic gown as she entertained the 20,000 strong audience with a selection of her most famous hits. Katy's impressive vocals were accompanied by an incredible light show and pyrotechnics as the audience cheered for more. One of the light up drones formed a tiger's head in a nod to her hit Roar  Beaming Katy thanked his majesty for the privilege and revealed her honour as she gushed: 'I got to bring my mum and stay in a castle!'.  Her show stopping frock featured a sculpted bodice with plunging neckline as well as an enormous princess skirt that made sure she could be seen from far and wide.

The gown also boasted quirky sleeves with puff detailing at the shoulders and she completed the look with large gold earrings, before later sharing  her post which displayed the delicate embroidery on the inside.

Following her own Instagram post, Orlando posted a picture of the concert on his own Instagram page, writing: 'Immensely proud of you my my love. You always bring the light', under which she responded: 'Our light'. Elsewhere during the show Tom Cruise made a surprise cameo in a surprise pre-recorded segment.The A-list actor, 60, was flying his iconic Top Gun plane in the cameo during an interlude between performances as stars including Pierce Brosnan and Bear Grylls discussed the King's military service.A clip of Tom then came up on the screen as he flew a plane and quipped: 'Pilot to pilot - your Majesty, you can be my wingman anytime!'

King Charles served in both the Navy and air force during his military career between 1971 and 1994.  Top Gun: Maverick star Tom is known for his love of flying and appeared in the P-51 Mustang which featured in the film. The cameo was part of a series of pre-recorded sketches revealing little-known facts about the monarch. The King and Queen of the royal family joined around 20,000 members of the public at the Coronation Concert to continue the celebrations after their crowning at Westminster Abbey on Saturday.

The Coronation Concert also saw performances by Paloma Faith Lionel Richie and veteran rock guitarist Steve Winwood. The show in Windsor, which was hosted by Downton Abbey and Paddington star Hugh Bonneville, started at 8pm. Buckingham Palace promised 'global music icons and contemporary stars' for the big concert. It was the highlight of the second day of coronation celebrations with around 20,000 members of the public attending.Classical acts including Andrea Bocelli, Welsh bass-baritone Sir Bryn Terfel and Chinese pianist Lang Lang were also on the bill.
